translations: The rabbit sends little Bill It was the White Rabbit who was slowly trotting back, anxiously looking around as if it had lost something; and she heard it murmuring: "The Duchess!
The Duchess!
Oh, my poor paws!
Oh, my fur, my whiskers!
She will have me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets!

Where can I have dropped them, I wonder?" Alice quickly guessed that it was looking for the fan and the white gloves, and good-naturedly began to look for them, but they were nowhere to be seen – everything seemed to have changed since her bath in the pond, and the large hall with the glass table and the little door had completely disappeared.
Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice as she was searching around and angrily called out to her: "Well, Mary Ann, what are you doing here?
Run home at once and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan!
Hurry, hurry!" And Alice was so startled that she immediately ran in the direction it pointed and didn't even try to clarify the misunderstanding.
"It has taken me for its housemaid," she said to herself as she ran.
"How surprised it will be when it finds out who I am!

But I better bring it the fan and the gloves – that is, if I can find them." As she said this, she came to a neat little house, at the door of which was a shiny brass plaque engraved with the name "W.
RABBIT."
She entered without knocking and hurried up the stairs in great fear of encountering the real Mary Ann and being thrown out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
"How strange it seems," Alice said to herself, "to be doing errands for a rabbit!
"Maybe Dinah will have orders for me soon!" And she began to imagine the way it would happen: "Alice!
Come here right now and get ready for the walk!" "I'll be right there!

"I just have to guard this mouse hole until Dinah comes back, and make sure the mouse doesn't escape." But I don't think," Alice continued, "that they would let Dinah stay in the house if she started ordering people around!" In the meantime, she had stepped into a tidy little room with a table by the window, and on the table lay (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white gloves; she grabbed the fan and a pair of gloves and was just about to leave the room when her gaze fell on a little bottle that stood next to the mirror.
This time there was no label with the inscription "DRINK ME" on it, but nonetheless she uncorked it and brought it to her lips.
"I know that something interesting is bound to happen," she said to herself, "whenever I eat or drink something; so I want to see what this bottle does.

I just hope it makes me grow again, because I really have had enough of being such a tiny little thing!" This indeed happened, and much sooner than she had expected; before she had emptied half the bottle, she felt her head pressing against the ceiling, and she had to curl up to avoid breaking her neck.
She quickly set the bottle down, saying to herself, "That's enough – I -- I hope I don't grow any more – now I can't get out the door – I wish I hadn't drunk so much!" But alas!
It was too late for that!

She kept growing and soon had to kneel on the floor; in the next minute there wasn't even enough space for that, and she now tried to lie down with one elbow pressed against the door and the other arm wrapped around her head.
Still growing, she stuck one arm out of the window and one foot into the fireplace, saying, "I can't do anything more, whatever happens.

What will become of me?" To Alice's luck, the little magic bottle had reached its full effect, and Alice no longer grew; nevertheless, it was very uncomfortable, and since there seemed to be no way to ever get out of the room again, it was no wonder that she felt unhappy.
"It was much more pleasant at home," thought poor Alice, "when you weren't always getting bigger and smaller and when mice and rabbits weren't giving you orders.
I almost wish I hadn't gone down the rabbit hole – and yet – and yet – it is rather curious to live like this!
I just wonder what could have happened to me!
Whenever I read fairy tales, I thought that such things could never happen, and now I am right in the middle of a fairy tale.
A book should be written about me, it should!

And when I grow up, I will write one – but I am already grown up now," she added worriedly, "at least there is no more room here to grow any further." "But," thought Alice, "will I never be older than I am now?
That would be an advantage on one hand – never becoming an old woman – but on the other hand – always having to do homework!
I wouldn't like that at all!" -- 21 of 161 -- - 19- "Oh, you silly Alice!" she answered herself.
"How can you do homework here?

There is hardly any space for you, let alone for any school books!" And so she continued to consider one side and then the other, making a proper conversation out of it; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside and paused to listen.
"Mary Ann!
Mary Ann!" called the voice.
"Bring me my gloves at once!" Then the patter of little feet could be heard on the stairs.

Alice knew it was the rabbit coming to check on her, and she trembled so that the house shook, completely forgetting that she was now about a thousand times bigger than the rabbit and had no reason to be afraid of it.
Meanwhile, the rabbit reached the door and tried to open it; but since the door opened inwards and Alice's elbow was pressed firmly against it, this attempt failed.

Alice heard it say to itself: "Then I will go around and climb in through the window." "You won't!" thought Alice, and after waiting until she believed she could hear the rabbit directly under the window, she suddenly stretched out her hand and grabbed at the air.

She caught nothing, but she heard a small scream, a fall, and the clinking of broken glass, from which she concluded that the rabbit had possibly fallen into a glassed-in cucumber patch or something like that.
Next came an angry voice – the rabbit's – "Pat!
Pat!
"Where are you?" And then a voice she had never heard before: "Of course I'm here!"
"Dig up the potatoes, Your Grace!" "Alright!"
"Dig up the potatoes!" said the rabbit angrily.
"Over here!"
"Come and help me out of here!" (Another crash of glass.) "Now tell me, Pat, what is that in the window?" "Of course, it's an arm, Your Grace!" (He pronounced it like "Aam.") "An arm, you fool!
Where would you find one that size?
It fills the whole window!" "Of course it does, Your Grace, but it's still an arm." "Well, in any case, it has no business being there.

Go and get rid of it!" After that, there was a long silence, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then, like "Of course I don't like it, Your Grace, not at all, not at all!" – "Do what I say, you coward!" and finally she stretched out her hand again and reached into the air.
This time there were two small screams and more crashing of broken glass. "What a lot of cucumber beds there must be here!" thought Alice.
"I wonder what they will do next!
If they want to drag me out of the window, I only wish they could!

I definitely do not want to stay in here any longer!" She waited for a while, without hearing anything more; finally, she heard the rumbling of small cart wheels and the sound of many voices all talking at once; she could make out the following words: "Where is the other ladder?
– Why, I was only supposed to bring one, Bill has the other – Bill, bring it here, my boy!
– Here, set it up in this corner – No, tie them together first – they are half a length too short – Oh, come on, they are long enough.
Don't be so fussy – Here, Bill!
Catch the rope – Will the roof hold?
– Watch out for the loose brick – Careful, it's coming down!
"Heads away!" (a loud crash) – "So, who was that?
– Bill, I assume – Who is climbing down the chimney?
– No, not me!
You do it!
– I'm not thinking about it!
– Bill should climb down – Hey, Bill!
The gentleman says you should climb down the chimney!" "Aha!
So Bill is supposed to climb down the chimney, right?" Alice said to herself.
"They seem to be piling everything onto Bill!
I definitely wouldn't want to be in Bill's place!

This chimney is narrow, but I think I can give him a little kick!" She pulled her foot down the chimney as far as she could and waited until she heard a small animal (she couldn't tell what kind it was) climbing and scratching just above her; then, while saying to herself, "So much for Bill!" she gave him a sharp kick and waited to see what would happen next.

The first thing she heard was the collective shout of everyone: "There goes Bill!", then the voice of the rabbit: "Catch him, you there by the hedge!", then silence, and then renewed chatter: "Hold his head up – now brandy – don't let him choke – How was it, old boy?
What happened to you?
"You have to tell us everything!" Finally, a small, weak, squeaky voice came.

("That's Bill!" thought Alice.) "Yes, I don't know – enough, thanks; I'm feeling better – but I'm still too confused to report to you – I only know that something is coming at me like a spring devil and I'm zooming off like a rocket!" "That's how it was, old boy!" the others said.

"We have to burn the house down!" said the rabbit's voice, and Alice shouted as loud as she could: "If you do that, I'll set Dinah on you!" Immediately there was dead silence, and Alice thought to herself: "What will they do now!"
If they only had a little sense, they would take the roof off." After a few minutes, they began to run around again, and Alice heard the rabbit say: "For a start, a wheelbarrow full will be enough."
"A wheelbarrow full of what?" thought Alice.
But she didn't have to guess for long, because in the next moment a hail of small pebbles clattered through the window, and some of them hit her in the face.
"I'll put an end to this," she said to herself and shouted loudly: "You'd better not do that again!", which resulted in dead silence once more.
To her surprise, Alice noticed that all the pebbles turned into cookies as soon as they hit the ground, and she had an epiphany.

"If I eat one of these cookies," she thought, "my size will definitely change, and since I can't possibly get bigger, I must be getting smaller." So she ate one of the cookies and was delighted to feel that she immediately began to shrink.
When she was small enough to go through the door, she ran out of the house and saw a crowd of small animals waiting outside.
Bill, the poor little lizard, was standing in the middle, supported by two guinea pigs who were pouring something from a bottle into him.
The moment Alice appeared, they all rushed towards her, but she ran away as fast as she could and soon found herself safely in a dense forest.
"The first thing I have to do," Alice said to herself as she wandered through the forest, "is to regain my proper size; and the second is to find the way to the magnificent garden.

I think that's the best plan." That certainly sounded like an excellent and neatly and simply arranged plan; the only difficulty was that she had not the slightest idea how to put it into action; and while she anxiously peered between the trees, a small sharp bark just above her head made her look up quickly.
A huge young dog looked down at her with big round eyes, gently extended its paw, and tried to touch her.

"Poor little thing!" said Alice in a flattering tone, and she eagerly tried to whistle to it, but all the while she was terribly frightened at the thought that it might be hungry and would very likely eat her in that case, despite all her flattery.

She hardly knew what she was doing when she picked up a small stick and held it out to the young dog: whereupon it jumped into the air, barking with joy, with all four paws at once, pounced on the stick, and pretended to want to grab it; Alice stepped behind a large thistle to avoid being trampled, and as soon as she came out on the other side, the puppy again pounced on the stick and tumbled head over heels in its haste to catch it; then Alice, who thought it was like a game with a cart horse and expected to be trampled to the ground at any moment, ran around the thistle again; and the young dog made a series of short advances towards the stick, each time running a very short distance forward while barking hoarsely, and a long distance backward, until he finally sat down a good way off, panting with his big eyes half-closed and his tongue hanging out.
That seemed to Alice a good opportunity to escape; she immediately made off and ran until she was quite tired and out of breath, hearing the barking of the young dog only faintly in the distance.
"And what a lovely little puppy it was!" said Alice as she leaned against a buttercup to rest and fanned herself with one of the leaves.
"I would have liked to teach it tricks if - if I had the right size for it!
Oh dear!
I almost forgot that I have to grow larger again!
But wait - how does one do it?
I suppose I must eat or drink something; but the big question is: what?" The big question was undoubtedly: what?
Alice looked around at the flowers and blades of grass, but she could see nothing that looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances.

Next to her stood a large mushroom, about as tall as she was, and when she had looked under it, beside it, and behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look to see what was on top. She stood on tiptoe and peered over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes met those of a large blue caterpillar sitting on top with its arms crossed, quietly smoking a long water pipe and taking no notice of her or anything else.

fest gegen den Fuß gepreßt, daß sie kaum Platz genug hatte, den Mund zu öffnen, aber dann gelang es ihr

* * * * *
„So, mein Kopf ist endlich frei!“ sagte Alice erfreut, war aber im nächsten Moment beunruhigt, als sie ihre

„Was kann nur all dieses grüne Zeug sein?“ sagte Alice. „Und wo sind meine Schultern hingeraten? Und ach!

unter zu ihnen zu bringen, und war erfreut zu spüren, daß sich ihr Hals leicht in jede Richtung wie eine
Schlange bog. Gerade war es ihr gelungen, ihn in graziösem Zickzack hinabzubeugen, um mit ihm unter die

„Schlange!“ kreischte die Taube.
„Ich bin keine Schlange!“ rief Alice empört. „Laß mich in Ruhe!“
„Schlange, sage ich!“ wiederholte die Taube in gedämpfterem Ton und fügte mit einem Schluchzen hinzu:
„Alles habe ich versucht, aber nichts scheint ihnen zu passen!“
„Ich habe nicht die geringste Idee, wovon du sprichst,“ sagte Alice.

auf Alice zu hören, „aber diese Schlangen! Nichts gefällt ihnen!“

„Aber ich bin keine Schlange, sage ich dir!“ rief Alice. „Ich bin – ich bin –“
„Na? Was bist du?“ sagte die Taube. „Ich sehe schon: Du versuchst, dir etwas auszudenken.“

„Ein schönes Märchen, in der Tat!“ sagte die Taube im Ton tiefster Verachtung. „Ich habe in meinem Leben

„Freilich habe ich Eier gegessen,“ sagte Alice; die ein sehr wahrheitsliebendes Kind war, „aber kleine Mäd -
chen essen Eier ebenso oft wie Schlangen, mußt du wissen.“

mit basta!“

translations: Good Advice from a Caterpillar The caterpillar and Alice looked at each other silently for a while; finally, the caterpillar took the pipe out of its mouth and spoke to Alice in a dull, sleepy voice.
"Who are you?" said the caterpillar.
That was not an encouraging start to a conversation.

Alice replied quite shyly, "I – I hardly know at the moment, my lord – I know who I was when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then." "What do you mean by that?" said the caterpillar sternly.
"Explain that!" "I'm afraid, my lord, I can't explain it," said Alice, "because, you see, I am not myself." "I don't see it," said the caterpillar.

"I can't express it more clearly, I'm afraid," replied Alice very politely, "because I can't understand it myself, and having so many different sizes in one day is very confusing." "Is it not," said the caterpillar.

"Well, perhaps you haven't felt it that way yet," said Alice, "but when you become a doll – you will one day – and then a butterfly, you will feel a bit strange, I believe, won't you?" "Not a bit," said the caterpillar.
"Well, perhaps your feelings may be different," said Alice, "I only know that I would feel very strange." "You!" said the caterpillar disdainfully.
"Who are you?" With that, they had returned to the beginning of the conversation.

Alice was a little irritated because the caterpillar made such particularly short remarks; she took a stance and said weightily, "I believe you should tell me first who you are." "Why?" said the caterpillar.
That was yet another confusing question; and as Alice could not think of a reasonable reason and the caterpillar seemed to be in a very unpleasant mood, she turned to leave.
"Come back!" called the caterpillar after her.
"I have something important to say!" That certainly sounded promising.
Alice turned around and came back.
"Don't lose your temper!" said the caterpillar.
"Is that all?" said Alice, swallowing her anger as best she could.
"No," said the caterpillar.
Since Alice had nothing else to do, she thought she might as well wait; perhaps the caterpillar would still share something worth listening to.

It puffed away for several minutes without speaking; but finally, it unfolded its arms, took the water pipe out of its mouth, and said: "So you believe you have been transformed, yes?" -- "I fear so, my lord," said Alice, "I can't remember as well as I usually do – and I don't stay the same size for ten minutes!" "What can you not remember?" said the caterpillar.
"Well, I tried to recite 'How the little bee struggles,' but it came out completely different!" replied Alice sadly.
"Recite 'You are old, Father William,'" said the caterpillar.

Alice folded her hands and began: "You are old, Father William, so your hair is white," said the son, "completely white all through, and yet you still stand on your head – do you really think that suits an old man?" "When I was young," the father told the son, "I was afraid my mind would be injured.

But now, knowing that I am completely lacking it, well, I do it continuously." "You are old," said the son, "you surely admit that, and you are as thick as a mighty barrel; yet you turn a somersault through the door – now tell me, how do you explain that?" -- "In my youth," replied the wise man cheerfully, "I gave flexibility to my joints through the use of this salve: one little pot is enough!
Be good, and I will give you one." "You are old," said the son, "and what harder than mush can your jaw possibly endure; you devoured the goose along with bones and feet – how do you do it?

You must tell me." -- "I dealt with the law for a long time and discussed every case with the old woman; disputes do not harm the jaws, their strength has thus been preserved." "You are old," said the son, "but you do not feel it, because your eye still looks so steady; you balanced an eel on your nose – what makes you so terribly skillful?" "I answered three questions, but now I no longer engage in this nonsense.
Yes, do you think I have nothing better to do?
Go away, or you'll get a kick!" "That was not recited correctly," said the caterpillar.

"Not quite right, I'm afraid," said Alice timidly, "some of the words were swapped." "It is wrong from beginning to end," said the caterpillar decisively; and then there was silence for a few minutes.
The caterpillar was the first to speak again.
"What size would you like to be?" it asked.
"Oh, I'm not picky about size," Alice replied hastily, "you just don't want to change it too often, you know." "I don't know," said the Caterpillar.
Alice said nothing; in her whole life, she had never been contradicted so often, and she felt that she was slowly losing her composure.
"Are you satisfied now?" said the Caterpillar.

"Well, I would like to be a little bigger, sir, if you don't mind," said Alice, "eight centimeters is such a miserable size." "On the contrary, it is a very nice size!" said the Caterpillar angrily, sitting up straight (she was exactly eight centimeters tall).

"But I'm not used to it!" pleaded poor Alice in a pitiful tone, and she thought, "If only the creatures weren't so easily offended!" "You will get used to it in time," said the Caterpillar, putting the pipe in her mouth and starting to smoke again.
This time, Alice waited patiently until she decided to continue speaking.
After a minute or two, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of her mouth, yawned a few times, and shook herself.
Then she got down from the mushroom and crawled away through the grass, only noting: "One side makes you bigger and the other side makes you smaller." "One side of what?
The other side of what?" thought Alice.
"Of the mushroom," said the Caterpillar as if Alice had asked aloud, and in the next moment, she was out of sight.
Alice looked at the mushroom thoughtfully for a while and tried to figure out where its two sides were; and since it was completely round, this problem seemed very difficult to her.
Finally, however, she wrapped her arms around it as far as they would reach and broke off a piece from the edge with each hand.
"And which is which now?" she asked herself, nibbling a little on the right piece to test the effect.
In the next moment, she felt a strong push under her chin: it had bounced against her feet!
She was quite startled by this sudden change, but since she quickly shrank, there was no time to lose, and she immediately tried to eat some of the other piece.
Her chin was pressed so firmly against the foot that she hardly had enough room to open her mouth, but then she managed to do so, and she was able to swallow a crumb of the left piece.

“So, my head is finally free!” said Alice happily, but in the next moment she was disturbed when she could not find her shoulders anywhere; all she saw when she looked down was an enormously long neck that seemed to stretch like a stem from a sea of green leaves far below her.
“What can all this green stuff be?” said Alice.
“And where have my shoulders gone?
And oh!
my poor hands, why can’t I see you?” She moved them back and forth as she spoke, but it seemed that nothing happened except a slight movement in the distant green leaves.

-- 30 of 161 -- - 28 - As there seemed to be no way to lift her hands up to her head, she tried to bring her head down to them and was pleased to feel that her neck bent easily in every direction like a snake.

Just as she managed to bend it down in a graceful zigzag to dive under the leaves, which were nothing but the treetops she had wandered beneath, a sharp hissing made her quickly pull back: a large pigeon had flown into her face and was beating her fiercely with its wings.
“Snake!” screeched the pigeon.
“I am not a snake!” cried Alice indignantly.

“Leave me alone!” “Snake, I say!” repeated the pigeon in a quieter tone and added with a sob: “I’ve tried everything, but nothing seems to suit them!” “I have not the slightest idea what you are talking about,” said Alice.
“I’ve tried it with tree roots, with riverbanks, and with hedges,” continued the pigeon, not listening to Alice, “but these snakes!
Nothing pleases them!” Alice became more and more confused, but she thought it was no use saying anything more until the pigeon had finished.
“As if it wasn’t enough trouble hatching the eggs,” said the pigeon, “no, day and night I must still look out for snakes.
I haven’t found a minute of sleep in the last three weeks!” “I’m very sorry you’ve been disturbed,” said Alice, who was beginning to understand.

"And just as I had chosen the tallest tree in the forest," the dove continued, raising her voice to a scream, "and just as I believed I was finally free from them, they had to slither down from the sky!"
"Ugh, snake!" "But I'm not a snake, I tell you!" Alice shouted.
"I am - I am - " "Well?"
What are you?" said the dove.
"I see: you're trying to make something up." "I - I am a little girl," Alice said doubtfully, as she thought of the number of changes she had gone through that day.
"A lovely fairy tale, indeed!" said the dove in a tone of deepest contempt.
"I've seen a lot of little girls in my life, but not one with such a neck!
No, no, you are a snake, and there's no point in denying it.

I suspect that next you'll tell me you've never eaten an egg!" "Of course I've eaten eggs," said Alice; who was a very truthful child, "but little girls eat eggs just as often as snakes, you must know." "I don't believe that," said the dove, "but if they do, then they are just a kind of snake, and that's that!" This was such a new idea for Alice that she was quiet for a while, which gave the dove the opportunity to add: "You are looking for eggs, I know that for sure; and what does it matter whether you are a little girl or a snake?" "It matters a great deal to me," said Alice quickly, "but by chance I am not looking for eggs, and if I were, I wouldn't want yours: I don't like them raw."
Alice ducked under the trees as best as she could, for her neck kept getting caught in the branches, and now and then she had to stop and free it.

After a while, she remembered that she was still holding the mushroom pieces in her hands, and she began very cautiously to nibble on one, then the other: she grew larger and smaller until she managed to reach her normal size.

It had been a long time since she had been anywhere near her proper size; therefore, she felt quite strange at first, but in a few minutes she had gotten used to it and began to talk to herself as usual: "So, half of my plan is accomplished!
How confusing all these changes are!
I am never sure what I might become from one minute to the next!

But I have regained my proper size; the next thing is to get into that beautiful garden - but how, I wonder." As she said this, she suddenly came upon a clearing where a small house, a little over a meter high, stood.

"Whoever lives there," thought Alice, "would not be able to bear that I meet him at this size; he would lose his mind from shock!" Therefore, she nibbled again on the right piece and did not dare to approach the house until she had shrunk to 25 centimeters.

So setzte sie das kleine Geschöpf ab und war recht erleichtert zu sehen, wie es still in den Wald davontrabte.
„Wäre es größer geworden,“ sagte sie sich, „hätte es sich zu einem furchtbar häßlichen Kind entwickelt; aber

Krallen und mächtig viele Zähne, so daß Alice das Gefühl hatte, man müsse sie mit Respekt behandeln.

fort: „Würdest du mir bitte sagen, welchen Weg ich von hier einschlagen soll?“
„Das hängt vor allem davon ab, wo du hinkommen willst,“ sagte die Katze.
„Das ist mir ziemlich egal –“ sagte Alice.
„Dann spielt es keine Rolle, welchen Weg du einschlägst,“ sagte die Katze.
„– solange ich irgendwohin komme,“ fügte Alice als Erklärung hinzu.
„Oh, dessen kannst du sicher sein,“ sagte die Katze, „wenn du nur weit genug gehst.“
Alice sah ein, daß dies nicht geleugnet werden konnte, und so versuchte sie es mit einer anderen Frage. „Was

„In dieser Richtung,“ sagte die Katze und schwenkte die rechte Pfote, „wohnt ein Hutmacher; und in dieser
Richtung,“ sie schwenkte die andere Pfote, „wohnt ein Märzhase. Besuche, wen du willst: verrückt sind sie
beide.“

„Oh, da kommst du nicht drum herum,“ sagte die Katze. „Wie sind hier alle verrückt. Ich bin verrückt. Du
bist verrückt.“
„Woher weißt du, daß ich verrückt bin?“ sagte Alice.
„Du mußt es sein,“ sagte die Katze, „sonst wärst du nicht hergekommen.“
Alice hielt das keineswegs für einen Beweis; sie fuhr jedoch fort: „Und woher weißt du, daß du verrückt
bist?“
„Fangen wir damit an,“ sagte die Katze, „ein Hund ist nicht verrückt. Gibst du's zu?“
„Na schön,“ sagte Alice.
„Nun,“ fuhr die Katze fort, „du weißt, daß ein Hund knurrt, wenn er wütend ist, und mit dem Schwanz we-
delt, wenn er sich freut. Ich hingegen knurre, wenn ich mich freue, und wedele mit dem Schwanz, wenn ich

„Ich nenne das Schnurren, nicht Knurren,“ sagte Alice.
„Nenne es wie du willst,“ sagte die Katze. „Spielst du heute mit der Königin Krocket?“

translations: Pepper and Pig A few minutes she stood there and looked over at the house, considering what she should do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the woods – (she took him for a footman because he was in livery, otherwise she would have called him a fish just judging by his face) – and knocked loudly on the door.
She was opened by another footman in livery, with a round face and big eyes like a frog, and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that was curled all over their heads.
She was very curious about what all this meant, and crept a little closer out of the woods to listen.
The fish-footman pulled out from under his arm a huge letter, almost as big as he was, and handed it to the other one, speaking in a solemn tone: “For the Duchess.
An invitation from the Queen to play croquet.” The frog-footman repeated this in the same solemn tone, but changed the order of the words a little: “From the Queen.
An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.” Then both bowed deeply, and their curls got tangled together.

Alice laughed so much at this that she had to run back into the woods for fear someone might hear her; and when she peeked out again, the fish-footman had disappeared and the other one was sitting on the ground next to the door, staring stupidly at the sky.
Alice shyly approached the door and knocked.
“There’s no use knocking,” said the footman, “for two reasons.
First, because I am on the same side of the door as you are.

Second, because they are making such a racket inside that no one could possibly hear you.” And indeed there was a most unusual noise coming from inside – a constant howling and sneezing, and from time to time a great crash, as if a bowl or pot were breaking into pieces.
“Oh please,” said Alice, “how am I to get in?” “Your knocking would make sense,” the footman continued, without paying attention to her question, “if we had the door between us.
For example, if you were inside, you could knock and I could let you out, right?” While he was speaking, he kept looking up at the sky the whole time, and this seemed decidedly rude to Alice.
“But perhaps he can’t help it,” she said to herself, “his eyes are so far up on his head.
But in any case, he could answer questions.
"How am I supposed to get in?" she repeated loudly.

"I will sit here," remarked the footman, "until tomorrow—" At that moment, the front door opened and a large plate came sailing out, heading straight for the footman's head; it barely grazed his nose and shattered against one of the trees behind him.
"—or maybe the day after tomorrow," the footman continued in the same tone as if nothing had happened.
"How am I supposed to get in?" Alice asked again, this time louder.
"Are you even supposed to get in?" said the footman.
"That is indeed the crucial question." It was, without a doubt, but Alice did not want to be reminded of it.
"It is really terrible," she muttered to herself, "how the creatures here argue.
It is enough to make one crazy." The footman apparently thought it was a good opportunity to repeat his remark, and with variations.
"I will," he said, "sit here and sit here, day in, day out." "But what am I supposed to do?" said Alice.
"Whatever you want," said the footman and began to whistle.
"Oh, it's no use talking to him," said Alice desperately, "he's completely daft!" And she opened the door and stepped inside.

The door led directly into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from one end to the other; in the middle sat the Duchess on a three-legged stool, holding a baby on her lap; the cook leaned over the fire and stirred in a large cauldron that seemed to be full of soup.
"There must be too much pepper in the soup!" Alice told herself, as far as she could manage through all the sneezing.
-- 34 of 161 -- - 32 - There was certainly too much of it in the air.
Even the Duchess sneezed occasionally, and as for the baby, it alternated between sneezing and wailing without any pause.
The only two creatures in the kitchen that were not sneezing were the cook and a large cat that lay by the stove grinning from ear to ear.
"Please can you tell me," Alice began a little shyly, as she was not quite sure if it was polite to speak first, "why your cat is grinning?" "It's a Cheshire cat," said the Duchess, "that's why."

"Pig!" She exclaimed the last word with such sudden intensity that Alice jumped; but in the next moment, she saw that it was addressed to the baby and not to her; therefore, she gathered her courage and started again: "I didn't know that Cheshire cats always grin; in fact, I didn't know that cats could grin at all." "All can," said the Duchess, "and most do."
"You don't know much," said the Duchess, "and that's a fact." Alice did not like the tone of this remark at all and thought it would be better to bring up another topic of conversation.

While she was trying to think of one, the cook took the soup pot off the fire and immediately began throwing everything within her reach at the Duchess and the baby – first came the fire irons, then a hail of saucepans, plates, and bowls.
The Duchess took no notice of it, even when she was hit, and the baby was already crying so loudly that it was completely impossible to tell whether the hits hurt it or not.
"Oh please, pay attention to what you're doing!" cried Alice, who was jumping up and down in distress.
"Oh, his precious little nose!" as an unusually large saucepan flew past it and nearly knocked it off.

"If everyone took care of their own business," growled the Duchess hoarsely, "the world would spin a good deal faster." "That wouldn't be an advantage," said Alice, who was very glad of the opportunity to show off a bit of her knowledge.
"Just think of the difficulties there would be with day and night!

As you know, the Earth takes twenty-four hours to rotate on its axis—" "By the way, axe," said the Duchess, "chop off its head!" Alice cast a rather anxious glance at the cook to see if she had understood the hint, but the cook was busy stirring the soup and seemed not to be listening, so she began again: "Twenty-four hours, I believe, or is it twelve?

I—" "Oh leave me alone with that," said the Duchess, "I've never been able to stand numbers!" And with these words, she began rocking her child again, singing it some sort of lullaby and giving it a violent shake at the end of each line: – "Speak roughly to your little boy And beat him when he sneezes; He only does it to annoy And because he makes you cross." -- 35 of 161 -- - 33 - Chorus (in which the cook and the baby joined in): – "Wow!
Wow!

Wow!" While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she continued to shake the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing cried so much that Alice could hardly understand the words: – "I speak sternly to my son And beat him when he sneezes; He likes the pepper, you see, And only pretends, the beast!" Chorus "Wow!
Wow!
Wow!" "Here!
"You can hold it for a while if you want," said the Duchess to Alice, throwing the baby at her.
"I must go and get ready to play croquet with the Queen," and she hurried out of the room.
The cook threw a frying pan at her but just missed.
Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, for it was a strangely shaped little creature and stretched its arms and legs in all directions, "– just like a starfish," thought Alice.
The poor little thing puffed like a steam engine as she caught it, curling up and stretching out again, so that she could hardly hold it at first.

As soon as she had figured out the right method (one had to tie it into a sort of knot and then hold it by the right ear and left foot to keep it from coming undone again), she carried it out into the fresh air.
"If I don't take this child with me," thought Alice, "they will surely have it killed in a day or two.
Wouldn't it be murder to leave it there?" She said the last words aloud, and the little thing grunted in response (it had stopped sneezing now).
"Don't grunt," said Alice, "that's not at all an appropriate way to express yourself." The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to see what was the matter with it.
There was no doubt that it had a very turned-up nose, much more of a snout than a proper nose; its eyes were also unusually small for a baby: all in all, Alice did not like its appearance at all.
"But perhaps it just sobbed," she thought, looking again into its eyes to see if there were any tears in them.
No, there were no tears.
"If you want to turn into a pig, my dear," said Alice seriously, "I have nothing more to do with you.
Think about it in time!" The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible to tell), and they walked on for a while in silence.
Alice had just begun to think, "What am I going to do with this creature when I bring it home?" when it grunted again, so forcefully that Alice looked at its face in fear.
This time there was no doubt: it was nothing more and nothing less than a pig, and she felt it would be quite silly to carry it around any longer.
So she set the little creature down and was quite relieved to see it trot quietly into the woods.

"If it had grown larger," she said to herself, "it would have turned into a terribly ugly child; but I believe it will be a rather pretty pig." And she began to think of other children she knew who would have made quite good pigs, and she was just about to say, "If only one knew the right method to transform them—" when she was a little startled to see the Cheshire Cat sitting on a branch just a few feet away.
When the cat saw Alice, it just grinned.
It looks good-natured, thought Alice; but it had very long claws and a lot of teeth, so Alice felt that one should treat it with respect.
"Cheshire kitty," she began quite shyly, for she didn't know if the cat liked that name; however, the cat just grinned a little wider.
"Well, she's satisfied so far," thought Alice and continued, "Could you please tell me which way I should go from here?" "That depends a great deal on where you want to get to," said the cat.
"I don't much care where—" said Alice.
"Then it doesn't matter which way you go," said the cat.
"—as long as I get somewhere," Alice added as an explanation.
"Oh, you can be sure of that," said the cat, "if you only walk long enough." Alice realized that this could not be denied, so she tried another question.
"What kind of people live around here?" "In that direction," said the cat, waving its right paw, "lives a hat maker; and in that direction," it waved its other paw, "lives a March Hare.
Visit whom you like: they're both mad." "But I don't want to go among mad people," Alice remarked.
"Oh, you can't help that," said the cat.
"Everyone here is crazy."
"I am crazy."
"You are crazy." "How do you know that I am crazy?" said Alice.

"You must be," said the cat, "otherwise you wouldn't have come here." Alice did not consider that a proof at all; however, she continued: "And how do you know that you are crazy?" "Let's start with that," said the cat, "a dog is not crazy.
"Do you admit it?" "Alright," said Alice.
"Well," the cat continued, "you know that a dog growls when it is angry, and wags its tail when it is happy.
I, on the other hand, growl when I am happy, and wag my tail when I am angry.
That is why I am crazy." "I call that purring, not growling," said Alice.
"Call it what you like," said the cat.
"Are you playing croquet with the Queen today?" "I would very much like to," said Alice, "but I haven't been invited yet." "We'll see each other there," said the cat and disappeared.
Alice was not very surprised by that, as she had already gotten quite used to strange things happening.
While she was still looking at the spot where the cat had been sitting, it suddenly appeared again.
"By the way, what happened to the baby?" asked the cat.
"I almost forgot to ask." "It has turned into a pig," Alice replied quite calmly, as if the cat had returned in a natural way.
"I thought so," said the cat and disappeared again.
Alice waited for a while because she expected the cat to return, but it did not appear, and after a few minutes, Alice took the direction in which the March Hare was supposed to live.

"I've already seen the Hatter," she said to herself, "the March Hare will be far more interesting, and since it's now May, he might not be completely mad – at least not as mad as he was in March." As she said this, she looked up, and there sat the cat again on a branch.
"Did you say 'pig' or 'stone'?" asked the cat.
"I said 'pig,'" replied Alice, "and I wish you wouldn't keep appearing and disappearing so suddenly."

"You make me quite dizzy." "Well," said the cat, and this time it disappeared very slowly, starting with its tail and ending with the grin that lingered for a while after the rest had already vanished.
"I've often seen a cat without a grin," thought Alice, "but a grin without a cat!

That is the strangest thing I have ever seen in my life." -- 39 of 161 -- - 37 - She had not gone far when she spotted the March Hare's house; she thought it must be the right house because the chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was covered with fur.

It was such a large house that she did not want to approach any closer until she had nibbled a bit from the left side of the mushroom and had grown about 60 centimeters tall; even now she approached rather shyly, saying to herself, "Maybe he is still completely mad!
I almost wish I had gone to visit the Hatter instead!" -- 40 of 161 --

translations: A table was set under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were drinking tea there; between them sat a dormouse fast asleep, and the two others used it as a cushion, resting their elbows on it and talking over its head.
"Very uncomfortable for the dormouse," thought Alice.
"But since it is sleeping, I suppose it doesn't mind." The table was large, but all three were crowded together at one corner.
"No room!
No room!" they shouted when they saw Alice coming.
"There's plenty of room!" said Alice crossly, and sat down in a large armchair at one end of the table.
"Take some wine," said the March Hare in an encouraging tone.
Alice looked all over the table, but there was nothing but tea on it.
"I don't see any wine," she remarked.
"There isn't any," said the March Hare.
"Then it wasn't very polite of you to offer it," Alice replied angrily.
"It wasn't very polite of you to sit down without being invited," said the March Hare.
"I didn't know it was your table," said Alice, "it’s set for much more than three."
"Your hair needs cutting," said the Hatter.
He had been looking at Alice with great curiosity, and these were his first words.
"That is very rude." The Hatter's eyes widened very much when he heard this, but all he said was, "Why is a raven like a writing desk?" "Now we will have a little fun!" thought Alice.
"I'm glad they started with riddles - I think I can guess that," she added aloud.
"Do you think you think you could figure out the answer?" asked the March Hare.
"Exactly that," said Alice.
"Then you should say what you mean," the March Hare continued.
"I am," Alice replied hastily, "at least - at least I mean what I say - that's the same after all." "Not a bit the same!" said the Hatter.

"Then you might as well say: 'I see what I eat' is the same as 'I eat what I see'!" "You might as well say," the March Hare added, "that 'I like what I get' is the same as 'I get what I like'!" "You might as well say," added the Dormouse, who seemed to be speaking in his sleep, "that 'I live when I sleep' is the same as 'I sleep when I live'!" "With you, it's the same!" said the Hatter; here the conversation broke off and the company sat in silence for a minute, while Alice let everything she knew about ravens and writing desks go through her mind, and that wasn't much.
The Hatter was the first to break the silence.
"What day of the month is it today?" he asked, turning to Alice; he had pulled his watch out of his pocket and was looking at it restlessly, shaking it from time to time and holding it to his ear.
Alice thought for a moment and then said, "The fourth." "It’s been wrong for two days!" sighed the Hatter.
"I told you right away that butter damages the mechanism!" he added, glaring at the March Hare.
"It was the best butter," the March Hare replied meekly.

"Yes, but some crumbs must have gotten in," grumbled the Hatter, "you shouldn't have used the bread knife." The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily; then he dipped it into his teacup and looked at it again, but he couldn't think of anything better than to repeat his last remark: "It was the best butter." Alice had looked over his shoulder with great curiosity.
"What a funny watch!" she remarked.
"It tells the days of the month and not what time it is!" "Why should it?" grumbled the Hatter.

"Does yours perhaps indicate the year?" -- 42 of 161 -- - 40 - "Of course not," Alice replied wittily, "because it stays the same year for such a long time." "Which is exactly the case with mine," said the Hatter.
Alice was terribly confused.
The Hatter's remark seemed to contain no sense at all, and yet it was undoubtedly linguistically correct.
"I don't quite understand you," she said as politely as she could.
"The dormouse has fallen asleep again," said the Hatter, pouring a little hot tea on its nose.

The dormouse shook its head unwillingly and said, without opening its eyes: "Of course, of course: exactly what I was just about to say." "Have you solved the riddle yet?" asked the Hatter, turning back to Alice.
"No, I give up," replied Alice.
"What is the solution?" "I haven't the slightest idea," said the Hatter.
"Neither have I," said the March Hare.
Alice sighed wearily.

"I think you could do something better with your time," she said, "than waste it on riddles that have no solution." "If you knew time as well as I do," said the Hatter, "you wouldn't speak of it that way." "I don't know what you mean," said Alice.
"Of course you don't!" said the Hatter, tossing his head back contemptuously.
"I may assume that you've never even spoken to Time." "Maybe not," Alice replied cautiously, "but when our clock strikes the hours—" "Ah!
That explains everything," interrupted the Hatter.
"Time won't stand for strikes.
If you ever get on good terms with her, she will do almost anything you want with the clock.
Just suppose it’s nine o’clock in the morning – time to go to school: you only need to whisper a word to the time, and the hands will start running around like in flight!

Half-past one – time for lunch!” (“I only wish it were so,” whispered the March Hare to himself.) “That would indeed be great,” said Alice thoughtfully, “but, you know – I’m not hungry yet.” “Maybe not right away,” said the Mad Hatter, “but you could let it be half-past one for as long as you want.” “Is that how it is done here?” asked Alice.
The Mad Hatter shook his head sadly.
“Not me!” he replied.
“We had a quarrel in March – just before he went mad –” (he pointed with the teaspoon at the March Hare) “– it was at the big concert that the Queen of Hearts held, and I had to sing.
‘Twinkle, twinkle, bat, what are you getting at?’ Maybe you know the song?” “I’ve heard something similar before,” said Alice.
“It goes on like this,” continued the Mad Hatter: “Float along with a high-spirited mind like a tea tray.
Twinkle, twinkle –” Here the Dormouse shook himself and began to sing in his sleep: “Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle –” and wouldn’t stop, so that they had to pinch him to make him quiet.
“Well, I had hardly finished the first verse,” said the Mad Hatter, “when the Queen roared: ‘He just wants to kill time!
Off with his head!’” “How terribly barbaric!” cried Alice.
“And since then,” the Mad Hatter continued sadly, “time has not granted me any requests.
Now it’s always six o’clock.” A light went on for Alice.
“Is that the reason why so much tea set is laid out here?” she asked.
“Yes, that is it,” sighed the Mad Hatter, “it’s always tea time, and we don’t get a chance to wash the dishes in between.” “Then I suppose you move around the table?” said Alice.
"Right," said the Hatter, "always after a place setting has been used." "But what happens when you come back to the beginning?" Alice dared to ask.
"I suggest we talk about something else," interrupted the March Hare, yawning.
"I'm getting quite tired of it."
"I propose that the young lady tells us a story." "I'm afraid I don't know any," said Alice, quite disturbed by this suggestion.
"Then let the Dormouse!" both shouted.
"Wake up, Dormouse!" And they pinched her simultaneously from both sides.
The Dormouse slowly opened her eyes.
"I haven't been sleeping," she said in a weak, hoarse voice.
"I heard every word you fellows spoke." "Tell us a story!" said the March Hare.
"Yes, please," said Alice.

"And be quick about it," added the Hatter, "or you'll fall asleep again before it's finished." "Once upon a time there were three little sisters," the Dormouse began in great haste, "and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie, and they lived at the bottom of a well—" "What did they live on?" asked Alice, who was very interested in everything that had to do with food and drink.
"They lived on syrup," said the Dormouse, after thinking for a while.

"They probably couldn't do that well," Alice gently remarked, "they would have gotten sick." "They were," said the Dormouse, "very sick." Alice tried to imagine such an extraordinary way of life, but it confused her too much; so she continued, "But why did they live at the bottom of a well?" -- 44 of 161 -- - 42 - "Take some more tea," said the March Hare very seriously to Alice.

"I haven't had any so far," Alice replied angrily, "so I can't take any more." "You mean you can't take less," said the Hatter, "it's very easy to take more than nothing." "No one asked you for your opinion," said Alice.
"Who is making personal remarks now?" asked the Hatter triumphantly.

Alice didn't quite know what to say to that; so she took some tea and a buttered bread and turned to the dormouse, repeating her question: "Why did they live at the bottom of a well?" The dormouse thought for a while and then said: "It was a syrup well." "Such a thing doesn't exist!" Alice began very angrily, but the Mad Hatter and the March Hare went "Shh! Shh!" and the dormouse remarked grumpily: "If you can't behave, you'd better finish the story yourself." "No, please go on," said Alice very meekly.
"I won't interrupt you again."
"I do believe there may be one." "One, don't make me laugh!" said the dormouse irritably.
However, she allowed herself to continue: "So these three little sisters - they learned to pump - " "What did they pump?" asked Alice, forgetting her promise.
"Syrup," said the dormouse, this time without thinking.

"I would like a clean cup," interrupted the Mad Hatter, "let's all move one place down." He was already doing so while he spoke, and the dormouse followed him; the March Hare sat down in her chair, and Alice reluctantly moved to the March Hare's place.
The Mad Hatter was the only one who benefited from the change, and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, for the March Hare had just spilled the milk jug over his plate.
Alice didn't want to offend the dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: "But I don't understand.

Who did they pump the syrup from?" "You can pump water from a water well," said the Mad Hatter, "so you can surely pump syrup from a syrup well - can't you, dear?" "But they lived at the bottom of it," said Alice to the dormouse, deliberately ignoring the last remark.
"Of course," said the dormouse, "they lived there at the bottom." This answer confused poor Alice so much that she let the dormouse tell for a while without interrupting her.

"They learned to pump," continued the dormouse, yawning and rubbing her eyes, for she was getting very sleepy, "and they pumped all sorts of things - everything that starts with an A - " "Why with an A?" asked Alice.
"Why not?" asked the March Hare.
Alice was silent.
Alice was silent.

Meanwhile, the dormouse had closed her eyes and was dozing off, but pinched by the Hatter, she started up with a little shriek and went on: "—things that begin with an A, like amber and apple-cores and ambition and other things—you know they say 'it's all the same'—did you ever see pumped other things?" "Now that you ask me," said Alice in great confusion, "I don't think—" "Then you shouldn't talk," said the Hatter.

This rudeness was more than Alice could bear; outraged, she stood up and walked away; the dormouse fell asleep immediately, and none of the others took notice of Alice, although she looked back once or twice in the vague hope that they would call after her; the last thing she saw of them was that they were trying to stuff the dormouse into the teapot.
"I will definitely not go back there!" said Alice as she searched for a way through the forest.
"This is the stupidest tea party I have ever been to in my life." Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door that led straight into it.
"That is very strange!" she thought.
"But everything is strange today."
I think I can go in right away anyway." And she did.
Once again, she found herself in the long hall and at the little glass table.
"Now I will do it better," she said to herself and first took the little key and unlocked the door to the garden.

Then she nibbled on the mushroom (she still had a piece of it in her pocket) until she was about thirty centimeters tall; then she walked down the little corridor and then - she was finally in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower beds and the cool fountains.

Alice had never seen such a strange croquet ground in her life, as she believed; it consisted only of hills and ditches; the balls were live hedgehogs and the mallets were live flamingos, and the soldiers had to bend down and stand on their hands and feet to form the goals.

The main difficulty, Alice discovered first, was handling her flamingo: she managed to tuck its body quite comfortably under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but mostly, when its neck was nicely stretched out and she wanted to hit the hedgehog with its head, the flamingo turned around and looked at her with such a confused expression that she had to burst out laughing, and when she had bent its head down and wanted to start again, it was downright outrageous to find that the hedgehog had unrolled and was about to crawl away; moreover, there was usually a hill or a ditch right in the way where she wanted to send the hedgehog, and since the bending soldiers kept straightening up and moving to other parts of the ground, Alice soon concluded that it was indeed a very difficult game.

The participants all played at the same time, without waiting for their turn; they constantly argued and wrestled over the hedgehogs; and in a very short time, the queen was in a terrible mood and stomped around, shouting at least once every minute: "Off with his head!"

Alice waited until the eyes appeared, and then nodded.

"There's no point in speaking," she thought, "before her ears or at least one is there." After another minute, the whole head had appeared, and Alice set down her flamingo and began to report on the game, very glad that she had someone to listen to her.
The cat seemed to think that enough of her was in sight, and nothing further appeared.

"I don't think they all play fair," complained Alice, "and they all argue so terribly that you can't understand your own word – and above all, they seem to have no rules; at least they don't follow them if there are any – and you can't imagine how confusing it is with the living equipment: for example, the goal I have to go through next is running around at the other end of the ground – and right now I should have croqueted the queen's hedgehog, but when he saw me coming, he ran away!" "How do you like the queen?" asked the cat quietly.

"Not at all," said Alice, "she is so exceedingly –" At that moment, she noticed that the queen was standing right behind her and listening, so she continued: "– close to winning that it's hardly worth finishing the game." The queen smiled and moved on.
"Who are you talking to?" said the king, approaching Alice; he looked at the cat with great curiosity.

"This is a friend of mine – a Cheshire cat," said Alice, "allow me to introduce her to you." "I don't like her look at all," said the king, "but she may kiss my hand if she wishes." "I would rather not," remarked the cat.
"Don't be rude," said the king, "and don't look at me like that!" As he spoke, he positioned himself behind Alice.

"A cat may look at a king," said Alice, "I read that in a book, but I don't remember which one." "No matter, she must be removed," said the king very decisively; and he called out to the queen, who was just passing by: "My dear!

I would like you to have this cat removed!" The queen had only one method to eliminate all difficulties, whether big or small: "Off with her head!" she said, without even looking. "I will fetch the executioner myself," said the king eagerly and hurried away.
Alice thought she could also go back and see how the game was going when she heard the queen screaming in rage from afar.

She had already heard that three players had been sentenced to execution because they hadn't realized it was their turn, and she didn't like this situation at all because the game was so confusing that she never knew whether it was her turn or not.
Therefore, she went to look for her hedgehog.

The hedgehog was involved in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice a good opportunity to croquet one with the other; only the difficulty arose that her flamingo had gone to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying helplessly to fly up into a tree.

When she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over and both hedgehogs were out of sight; "but that doesn't matter much," thought Alice, "because all the gates have disappeared from this side of the court." So she tucked the flamingo under her arm to prevent it from escaping again and went back to chat a little more with her friend.

When she returned to the Cheshire cat, she found, to her surprise, a large crowd gathered around her; a dispute was taking place between the executioner, the king, and the queen, who were all speaking at once, while the others were completely silent and looked very embarrassed.

Alice had hardly arrived when she was asked by all three to settle the dispute, and they repeated their arguments for her, but since they were all speaking at once, it was very difficult for her to make out exactly what they were saying.

The executioner's argument was that one could not behead someone if there was no body from which to behead it, that he had never done such a thing before, and did not intend to start doing so at his age.
The king's argument was that anything with a head could be beheaded, and that one should not talk nonsense.
The queen's argument was that if something did not happen immediately, she would have them all beheaded as they stood.

(It was this last remark that made the whole company look so serious and anxious.) Alice could think of nothing else to say than, "She belongs to the Duchess; perhaps you should ask her about it." "She is in prison," said the queen to the executioner, "bring her here." And the executioner dashed away like an arrow.

As soon as he was gone, the cat's head began to fade, and when the executioner returned with the duchess, it had completely disappeared; the king and the executioner ran wildly back and forth to search for it, while the others returned to the game.

translations: - 50 CHAPTER IX The Story of the Mock Turtle "You have no idea how glad I am to see you again, old dear!" said the Duchess as she lovingly linked her arm with Alice's, and they walked on together.
Alice was very glad to see her in such good spirits and thought that perhaps it was the pepper that had made her so grim when they had met in the kitchen.
"When I am a Duchess," she said to herself (though not very hopefully), "I will not have any pepper in my kitchen at all.

Soup can taste very good without it – perhaps it is the pepper that makes people so hot-headed," she continued, very pleased that she had discovered a new rule, "– and vinegar makes it sour – and chamomile makes it bitter – and – and sweets and such good things make children sweet and dear.

I only wish people knew that, then they wouldn't be so stingy with it –" In the meantime, she had completely forgotten the Duchess and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear: "You are thinking about something, my dear, and that is why you forget to speak.
I can't tell you what the moral of it is right now, but it will come back to me in a moment." "Perhaps it has none," Alice ventured to remark.
"But my dear!" said the Duchess.
"Everything has a moral, you just have to find it." And as she spoke, she pressed closer to Alice.

Alice did not like having her so close; first, because the Duchess was very ugly, and second, because she was just the right size to rest her chin on Alice's shoulder, and it was an unpleasantly sharp chin.
However, she did not want to be rude, so she endured it as best she could.
"The game is going a bit better now," she said to keep the conversation going a little.

"That’s right," said the Duchess, "and the moral of it is – 'Oh, it’s love, love that makes the world go round!'" "Someone once said," whispered Alice, "that this is caused by everyone minding their own business!" -- 53 of 161 -- - 51 - "Well!

That means pretty much the same thing," said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice's shoulder as she added, "And the moral of it is – 'Self-interest is the beginning of all prosperity.'" "How she loves to find a moral everywhere!" thought Alice.
"I suppose you are wondering why I don't put my arm around your waist," said the Duchess after a pause, "the reason is that I doubt the good temper of your flamingo.
Should I take the risk?" "He might bite," said Alice cautiously, for she was not at all interested in the experiment.
"Very true," said the Duchess, "both flamingos and mustard bite.
And the moral of that is – 'Birds of a feather flock together.'" "Only mustard is not a flamingo," noted Alice.
"Right, as usual," says the Duchess, "how clearly you express the matter." "It's a mineral, I believe," said Alice.
"Of course," said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree with everything Alice said, "there's a large mustard mine nearby.
And the moral of that is – 'You must make a good face at a bad game.'" "Oh, now I know!" cried Alice, who had not paid attention to the last remark.
"It's a plant.

It may not look like it, but it is." "I completely agree with you," said the Duchess, "and the moral of that is – 'Be what you seem' – or if you want it said more simply – 'Never imagine yourself to be different from what others might think you were or could have been, as that would only appear to them to be different from what you had been.'" "I think I would understand it better," said Alice very politely, "if I had it written down in front of me, but when you say it, I can't quite follow." "That's nothing compared to what I could say if I wanted to," replied the Duchess flattered.
"Please don't bother to express it any longer," said Alice.
"Oh, don't speak of bother!" said the Duchess.
"Everything I've said so far, I give to you as a gift." "A cheap gift!" thought Alice.
"I'm glad that such gifts are not given for birthdays." But she did not dare to say it out loud.
"Are you thinking again?" asked the Duchess and poked again with her sharp little chin.
"I have a right to think," said Alice impatiently, for she was beginning to feel a little annoyed.

"Just as much right," said the Duchess, "as pigs have to fly; and the mo–" But here, to Alice's great surprise, the Duchess's voice died in the middle of her favorite word "moral," and the arm that was hooked in hers began to tremble.
Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen with her arms crossed and a face like a thunderstorm.
"A beautiful day, Your Majesty!" began the Duchess in a quiet, weak voice.
"I warn you!" shouted the Queen, stamping her foot on the ground.
"Either you are gone right now or your head, and that in no time at all!
Choose!" The Duchess chose and was instantly gone.
"We want to continue playing," said the Queen to Alice; and Alice was far too anxious to say a word, but slowly followed her to the croquet ground.

The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen's absence to rest in the shade; as soon as they saw her, however, they hurried back to the game, with the Queen only noticing that a moment's delay would cost them their lives.

Throughout the entire game, the Queen never stopped arguing and shouting with the other players: "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" The condemned were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to stop forming the gates, so that after about half an hour there were no more gates and all players except the King, the Queen, and Alice were arrested and sentenced to execution.

Then the Queen paused, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, "Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?" "No," said Alice, "I don't even know what a Mock Turtle is." "It's what you make Mock Turtle Soup from," said the Queen.
"I have never seen one or heard of one," said Alice.

"Then come," said the Queen, "she will tell you her story." As they walked away together, Alice heard the King quietly say to the whole company, "You are all pardoned." "Well, that's a fine thing!" she said to herself, for she had been quite unhappy about the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
Soon they came across a Gryphon, who was lying in the sun and fast asleep.
(If you don't know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) "Get up, lazybones!" said the Queen, "and take this young lady to the Mock Turtle, so she can hear her story.
I must go back and take care of some executions I have ordered," and she walked away, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon.
Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but all in all, she thought staying with it was just as safe as following that wild Queen; so she waited.
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes; then it watched the Queen until she was out of sight; then it giggled.
"Too funny!" said the Griffin, half to himself, half to Alice.
"What is funny?" asked Alice.
"Well, she," said the Griffin.
"It's all in her imagination, you see: she never executes anyone."
"Come on, let's go!" "Everyone says 'come!' here," thought Alice as she slowly followed.

"I have never been commanded around like this in my whole life!" They had not gone far when they saw the Mock Turtle sitting sadly and lonely on a small rock ledge in the distance, and as they got closer, Alice could hear her sighing as if her heart were breaking.
She felt very sorry for Alice.
"What is she sad about?" she asked the Griffin.
And the Griffin replied with almost the same words as before: "It's all in her imagination, you see: she has no sorrow at all."
"Come on, let's go!" So they went towards the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large, tear-filled eyes but said nothing.
"This young lady here," said the Griffin, "she wants to hear your story." "I will tell it to her," said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow voice.

"Sit down, both of you, and don't say a word until I am finished." So they sat down, and for a few minutes no one spoke, so that Alice thought: "I don't know how she can ever finish if she doesn't start." But she waited patiently.

"Once," said the Mock Turtle finally with a deep sigh, "I was real." These words were followed by a very long silence, interrupted only by the occasional exclamation of "Hjckrr!" from the Griffin and the continuous heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle.

Alice was close to getting up and saying, "Thank you, madam, for your interesting story," but she could not help but believe that there must be more to come; therefore, she remained seated and said nothing.
"When we were little," the Mock Turtle finally continued more calmly, although she still sobbed a little now and then, "we went to school in the sea."
The teacher was an old turtle – we used to call him sea elephant – “Why did you call him sea elephant if he wasn't one?” asked Alice.

“We called him sea elephant because he always said that he found the sea school with his soul,” said the false soup turtle angrily, “you are really very stupid!” “You should be ashamed to ask such a simple question,” added the griffin, and then both sat there silently looking at poor Alice, who would have preferred to sink into the ground.
Finally, the griffin said to the false soup turtle: “Go on, old one!
Don’t waste the whole day on it!” and she continued with these words: – “Yes, we went to school in the sea, although you might not believe it –” “I never said I didn’t believe it!” interrupted Alice.
“You did say it,” said the false soup turtle.
“Shut up!” added the griffin before Alice could respond.
The false soup turtle continued: “We received the best education – we went to school every day –” “I was also in a day school,” said Alice.
“You don’t need to imagine anything about that.” “With extras?” asked the false soup turtle somewhat worried.
“Yes,” said Alice, “we had French and music.” “And laundry?” asked the false soup turtle.
“Of course not!” said Alice indignantly.
“Aha!

Then yours wasn’t really a good school,” said the false soup turtle with great relief “Because at ours, the bill at the end included ‘French, music, and laundry – extra’.” “But you couldn’t have needed that often,” said Alice, “if you lived on the seabed.” “I couldn’t afford to learn it,” said the false soup turtle with a sigh.
“I only had the compulsory subjects.” “What were they?” asked Alice.

“First of all, of course, leaning and striding,” replied the false soup turtle, “and then the various kinds of arithmetic – wattling, stirring soup, mother pleating, and conducting.” “I’ve never heard of ‘mother pleating’,” said Alice.
“What is that?” The griffin raised his claws in surprise.
"Never heard of 'Mummy pleating'!" he exclaimed.

"But you know what pleating fabric is, I assume?" "Yes," Alice said hesitantly, "it means – making many folds in the fabric." "Well then," the Gryphon continued, "if you don't know what Mummy pleating is, you're a silly Trine." -- 57 of 161 -- - 55 - Alice did not feel encouraged to ask further; therefore, she turned to the Mock Turtle and said, "What else did you have to learn?" "Well, we had hysterical lessons," replied the Mock Turtle, counting the subjects on her flippers; "– old and new, with seaography; also dog lessons – this teacher was an old eel who came once a week: he taught us petting and dog history, but also boasting in flour." "What was that like?" Alice asked.
"I can't demonstrate that to you now," said the Mock Turtle.
"I don't have any flour here."
And the Gryphon never learned it at all." "No time," said the Gryphon.
"But I went to the classical teacher.
That was an old crab." "I never went to him," said the Mock Turtle with a sigh.
"He was never said to be nasty or mocking, they say." "That's true, that's true," said the Gryphon and it was now his turn to sigh; and both creatures buried their faces in their paws.
"And how many hours a day did you have lessons?" Alice asked to quickly change the subject.
"Ten hours on the first day," said the Mock Turtle, "nine the next, and so on." "What a strange timetable!" Alice exclaimed.

"That's why they're called hours," remarked the Gryphon, "because a further hour is granted to the students every day." This was a completely new idea for Alice, and she thought a little about it before making her next remark.
"Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?" "Of course," said the Mock Turtle.
"And how did you proceed on the twelfth?" Alice continued eagerly.
"Enough of that!" the Gryphon interrupted very decisively.
"Tell her now about the games." -- 58 of 161 --

„Das ist alles so merkwürdig, wie es nur sein kann,“ sagte der Greif.
„Alles kam anders heraus!“ wiederholte die Falsche Suppenschildkröte nachdenklich. „Ich möchte gern, daß

„Das ist anders als das, was ich aufgesagt habe, als ich ein

translations: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply and wiped her eyes with the back of a flipper.
She looked at Alice and tried to speak, but for a few minutes her voice was choked with sobs.
"Just like if she had a bone in her throat," said the Gryphon, and he began to shake her and poke her in the back.

Finally, the Mock Turtle regained her voice, and while the tears ran down her cheeks, she continued: - "You may not have lived long in the sea -" ("I haven't," said Alice.) - "and perhaps you've never been introduced to a lobster -" (Alice was just about to say: "I once tasted one -", but hastily stopped and said: "No, never") "- so you can't have any idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!" "No, indeed," said Alice.
"What kind of dance is that?" "Well," said the Gryphon, "first you form a line along the shore -" "Two lines!" shouted the Mock Turtle.
"Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you've cleared all the jellyfish out of the way -" "That usually takes some time," interrupted the Gryphon.
"- you take two steps forward -" "Each with a lobster as a partner!" shouted the Gryphon.
"Of course!" said the Mock Turtle.
"Two steps forward, turn to your partners -" "- change lobsters, and return in the same position," added the Gryphon.
"Then, you must know," continued the Mock Turtle, "you throw the -" "The lobsters!" cried the Gryphon and made a leap in the air.
"- as far as you can into the sea -" "Swim after them!" screeched the Gryphon.
"Do a somersault in the sea!" shouted the Mock Turtle and hopped around wildly.
"Change lobsters again!" bellowed the Gryphon at the top of his lungs.

"Back to land again, and - that's the whole first figure," said the Mock Turtle, suddenly lowering her voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping around like crazy the whole time, sat down again very sadly and quietly and looked at Alice.
"That must be a very pretty dance," said Alice timidly.
"Would you like to see a little bit of that?" asked the Mock Turtle.
"Really very much," said Alice.
"Come, we want to try the first figure!" said the Mock Turtle to the Griffin.
"We can also do it without lobsters.
Who should sing?" "Oh, you sing," said the Griffin.

"I've forgotten the text." -- 59 of 161 -- - 57 - So they began to dance solemnly around Alice, occasionally stepping on her toes when they came too close, and they waved their front paws to keep the beat, while the Mock Turtle sang this very slowly and sadly: - "Go faster!" said a White Thing and nudged a snail.

Do you think the lobsters and the seals care that they have to wait for us - you're joining the dance, right?
You are, you aren't, you are, you aren't, not joining the dance?

Too far!

Don't want to, can't be, don't want to, can't be joining the dance.
Don't want to, can't be, don't want to, can't be joining the dance.

"Because over there on the other side, fortunately, there is a wide beach." The further England is away, the closer France is – "Don't be scared, dear snail, and join in the dance!"
"You are, you are not, you are, you are not, but are you joining in the dance?"

"You are, you are not, you are, you are not, not joining in the dance?" "Yes," said Alice, "often at noon—" She quickly broke off.
"I don't know where noon might be," said the False Turtle, "but if you have seen it so often, then you know, of course, what they are like?" "I think so," replied Alice thoughtfully.
"They have their tails in their mouths and are covered all over with crumbs." "The thing about the crumbs is wrong," said the False Turtle, "crumbs would be washed away in the sea.

"The reason is," said the Griffin, "that they wanted to go dancing with the lobsters.
That's why they were thrown into the sea.
That's why they had to fly very far.
That's why they held their tails tightly in their mouths.
That's why they couldn't get them out again.
That's all." "Thank you," said Alice, "that's very interesting.

"Do you know why he is called Weißling?" "I never thought about it," said Alice.
"Why?" "Because he makes us believe many things," replied the Gryphon very solemnly.
"What does he make you believe?" asked Alice, astonished.

The Gryphon shook his head impatiently and said: "He makes us believe that he knows that he is wise."

"Now you know it." "If I had been the Weißling," said Alice, whose thoughts were still on the song, "I would have said to the Grundel: 'Please stay back!

And the Gryphon added: "Come, let us hear some of your adventures." "I could tell you my adventures - starting from this morning," said Alice a little hesitantly, "but it is pointless to go back to yesterday because I was a different person then." "Explain all that," said the Mock Turtle.
"First the adventures," said the Griffin impatiently.
"Explanations take such an awful lot of time." So Alice began to tell them her adventures from the moment she first saw the White Rabbit.
At first, she was a little nervous, with the two creatures close by her side, their eyes and mouths wide open, but as she continued to tell the story, she gained courage.

Her listeners were completely silent until she reached the part where she recited "You are old, Father William" in front of the Caterpillar, and the words all came out differently, and then the Mock Turtle took a deep breath and said, "That is very remarkable!" "That is as strange as it can possibly be," said the Griffin.
"Everything came out differently!" the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully.
"I would like her to try it now and recite something.
Tell her to start." She looked at the Griffin as if she thought he had authority over Alice.
"Get up and recite 'Hark! The voice of the Lazybones,'" said the Griffin.
"How the creatures command you around and ask for homework!" thought Alice.

"I might as well be in school." However, she got up and began to recite, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille that she hardly knew what she was saying, and indeed, very strange things came out: - "Hark! The voice of the lobster; he says loud and clear: 'Oh, you roasted me too brown, I must sugar my hair.' "Well, I've never heard it before," said the Mock Turtle, "but it sounds unusually silly." Alice said nothing.
She had sat down, her hands covering her face, and wondered if anything would ever happen in a normal way again.
"I would like it to be explained," said the Mock Turtle.
"She can't explain it," said the Griffin hastily.
"Continue with the next stanza." "But what about his toes?" insisted the Mock Turtle.
"How could he arrange her with his nose?" -- 62 of 161 -- - 60 - "It's the first position in dancing," said Alice, but she was terribly confused by the whole thing and longed to change the subject.
"Continue with the next stanza," the Griffin repeated.

"She begins, 'I came into the garden.'" Soup of the evening, glorious feast!
Soup of the evening, glorious feast!
Glor-rrious fea-aast!"
Wonderful feast!
Soup of the evening, wonderful, wonderful feast!
Wonderful soup!

Who among you wouldn't trade such stuff for the wonderful feast?
Such stuff for the wonderful feast?
Wonderful feast!
Wonderful feast!

"Soup of the evening, wonderful, wonderful feast!" "Once more the refrain!" shouted the Griffin, and the false turtle had just begun to repeat it when from afar the call "The trial is starting!" could be heard.
