chen ihres Alters die Bedeutung von alledem kannten. „Juroren“ wäre jedoch genauso gut gewesen.
Die zwölf Geschworenen schrieben alle sehr eifrig auf Tafeln. „Was machen sie da?“ flüsterte Alice dem

Sie tat dies so schnell, daß der arme kleine Geschworene (es war Bill, die Eidechse) überhaupt nicht fest-

gezwungen, für den Rest des Tages mit dem Finger zu schreiben, und das hatte sehr wenig Zweck, weil es

„Herold, verlies die Anklage!“ sagte der König.

„Ein Meister darin, hat die Herzkönigin
Die leckersten Törtchen gemacht.
Mit Diebstahl im Sinn schlich der Herzbube hin
Und hat sie fortgebracht.“
„Fällt euer Urteil,“ sagte der König zu den Geschworenen.
„Noch nicht, noch nicht,“ fiel das Kaninchen hastig ein, „da kommt noch eine ganze Menge vorher!“

„Ich bitte um Verzeihung, Majestät,“ begann er, „daß ich dies hier mit hereinbringe, aber ich war noch nicht

„Am fünfzehnten,“ sagte der Märzhase.
„Sechzehnten,“ sagte die Haselmaus.

te, was es war: Sie begann, wieder größer zu werden, und ihr erster Gedanke war, aufzustehen und den Saal
zu verlassen; aber dann entschloß sie sich dazubleiben, solange genug Platz für sie war.
„Ich wünschte, du würdest nicht so drängeln,“ sagte die Haselmaus, die neben ihr saß. „Ich kann kaum
atmen.“
„Ich kann nichts dafür,“ sagte Alice sehr kleinlaut, „ich wachse.“
„Du hast kein Recht, hier zu wachsen,“ sagte die Haselmaus.
„Rede doch keinen Unsinn,“ erwiderte Alice schon dreister, „wie du weißt, wächst du selber.“
„Ja, aber ich wachse in vernünftigem Tempo,“ sagte die Haselmaus, „nicht auf diese lächerliche Weise.“ Und

Währenddessen hatte die Königin den Hutmacher unausgesetzt an-
gestarrt und sagte, gerade als die Haselmaus den Saal durchquerte,
zu einem der Gerichtsdiener: „Bring mir die Liste der Sänger vom
letzten Konzert!“, worauf der unglückliche Hutmacher so zu zit-
tern anfing, daß er beide Schuhe verlor.
„Mach deine Aussage,“ wiederholte der König ärgerlich, „oder ich
lasse dich hinrichten, ob du nervös bist oder nicht!“
„Ich bin ein armer Mann, Majestät,“ begann der Hutmacher mit
bebender Stimme, „und ich hatte kaum mit Teetrinken angefangen
– höchstens für eine Woche oder so – und das Butterbrot wurde so
spärlich – und das Flimmern des Tees –“
„Das Flimmern des was?“ sagte der König.
„Es fing mit dem Tee an,“ erwiderte der Hutmacher.
„Seit wann fängt Flimmern mit T an?“ sagte der König scharf. „Willst du mich für dumm verkaufen?
Weiter!“
„Ich bin ein armer Mann,“ fuhr der Hutmacher fort, „und viele Dinge flimmerten schließlich – aber der

„Sagte ich nicht!“ unterbrach der Märzhase eilig.
„Doch!“ sagte der Hutmacher.
„Ich streite es ab!“ versetzte der Märzhase.
„Er streitet es ab,“ sagte der König, „laß das weg.“
„Nun, jedenfalls sagte die Haselmaus –“ fuhr der Hutmacher fort und blickte ängstlich umher, um zu sehen,

„Danach,“ sprach der Hutmacher weiter, „schmierte ich noch mehr Butterbrote –“

„Daran kann ich mich nicht erinnern,“ sagte der Hutmacher.

- 65 -

Der bedauernswerte Hutmacher ließ die Teetasse und das Butterbrot fallen und sich selbst auf ein Knie nie-

„Du bist ein sehr armseliger Redner,“ sagte der König.

„Wenn das alles ist, was du darüber weißt, kannst du dich niederlassen,“ fuhr der König fort.

„Dann kannst du dich niedersetzen,“ erwiderte der König.

„So, die Meerschweinchen sind wir los,“ dachte Alice, „jetzt werden wir besser vorankommen.“
„Ich würde lieber meinen Tee zu Ende trinken,“ sagte der Hutmacher mit einem ängstlichen Blick auf die

„Du kannst gehen,“ sagte der König, und der Hutmacher verließ eilig den Saal, ohne daß er sich wenigstens

„– und schlag ihm draußen gleich den Kopf ab,“
setzte die Königin zu einem der Gerichtsdiener ge-

„Ruft den nächsten Zeugen!“ befahl der König.

„Mach deine Aussage!“ sprach der König.
„Nö,“ sagte die Köchin.

„Woraus werden Törtchen gemacht?“

translations: When they arrived, the King and Queen of Hearts were sitting on their throne, and a large crowd had gathered around them: all kinds of small animals as well as the entire deck of cards; the Knave of Hearts was in chains before them, with a soldier guarding him on each side, and next to the King stood the White Rabbit, holding a trumpet in one hand and a scroll of parchment in the other.

Right in the middle of the courtroom stood a table, and on it was a large plate of tarts: they looked so delicious that Alice became quite hungry just from looking at them – “I wish they would finish the trial,” she thought, “and pass around the refreshments!” But there seemed to be no chance of that; so she began to look around at everything to pass the time.
Alice had never been in a courtroom before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased when she realized that she knew the names of almost everything.

“That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “you can tell by his big wig.” By the way, the judge was the King, and since he wore his crown over the wig (look at the cover picture if you want to know how he did that), he seemed to be feeling extremely uncomfortable, and it certainly wasn’t becoming.

“And that’s the jury,” thought Alice, “and these twelve creatures” (they were small mammals, birds, and others) “are the jurors.” She repeated this last word to herself two or three times and was quite proud of it, for she thought, and rightly so, that very few little girls her age knew the meaning of all that.
“Jurors” would have been just as good.
The twelve jurors were all writing very eagerly on their slates.
“What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon.

“There’s nothing to write before the trial has begun.” “They’re writing down their names,” the Gryphon whispered back, “for fear they might forget them before the trial is over.” “Nincompoops!” Alice began loudly, but she quickly stopped, for the White Rabbit shouted, “Silence in the courtroom!” and the King put on his glasses and looked around in confusion to see who had spoken.

Alice could see – as well as if she were looking over their shoulders – that all the jurors were writing “Nincompoops!” on their slates, and she could even see that one of them didn’t know how to spell it and had to ask his neighbor.
“There will be a nice mess on their slates before the trial is over!” thought Alice.
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
Of course, Alice couldn’t stand this; she went around the hall, stood behind him, and soon found an opportunity to take the pencil away.

She did this so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the lizard) couldn’t even tell what had happened to the pencil; after searching for it everywhere, he was finally – 65 of 161 – - 63 - forced to write with his finger for the rest of the day, and that was very little use because it left no mark on the slate.
"Herald, drop the charges!" said the king.
Thereupon, the White Rabbit blew the trumpet three times, unrolled the parchment, and read as follows: - "A master at it, the Queen of Hearts made the tastiest tarts.
With theft in mind, the Knave of Hearts sneaked in and took them away." "What is your verdict," said the king to the jurors.

"Not yet, not yet," the rabbit hastily interjected, "there's still a whole lot more to come!" "Call the first witness!" said the king, and the White Rabbit blew the trumpet three times and called out: "First witness!" The first witness was the Mad Hatter.
He came in with a cup of tea in one hand and a buttered bread in the other.
"I beg your pardon, Your Majesty," he began, "for bringing this in, but I hadn't finished my tea when I was summoned." "But you should be finished," said the king.
"When did you start?" The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the courtroom, arm in arm with the Dormouse.
"On the fourteenth of March, I believe," he said.
"On the fifteenth," said the March Hare.
"Sixteenth," said the Dormouse.
"Write that down," said the king to the jurors, and they diligently noted all three dates on their tablets, added them up, and converted the sum into shillings and pence.
"Take off your hat," said the king to the Hatter.
"It doesn't belong to me," said the Hatter.
"Stolen!" the king exclaimed and turned to the jurors, who immediately made a note of the offense.
"I offer it for sale," the Hatter added as an explanation.
"I don't have my own."
"I am a hat maker." Here the Queen put on her glasses and began to stare intently at the hat maker, who became pale and restless.

"Make your statement," the King continued, "and don't be nervous, or I will have you executed on the spot." This did not seem to encourage the witness at all; he continued to shift from one foot to the other, looked anxiously at the Queen, and in his confusion bit a large piece out of the teacup instead of the sandwich.

-- 66 of 161 -- - 64 - Just at that moment, Alice was seized by a strange feeling that she could not explain until she realized what it was: she began to grow larger again, and her first thought was to stand up and leave the hall; but then she decided to stay as long as there was enough space for her.
"I wish you wouldn't push so," said the dormouse, who was sitting next to her.
"I can hardly breathe." "It's not my fault," said Alice very quietly, "I'm growing." "You have no right to grow here," said the dormouse.

"Don't talk nonsense," Alice replied bolder, "as you know, you are growing too." "Yes, but I'm growing at a reasonable pace," said the dormouse, "not in this ridiculous way." And she stood up very grumpily and walked to the other side of the courtroom.

Meanwhile, the Queen had been staring at the hat maker continuously and said, just as the dormouse crossed the hall, to one of the court attendants: "Bring me the list of singers from the last concert!", whereupon the unfortunate hat maker began to tremble so much that he lost both shoes.

"Make your statement," the King repeated angrily, "or I will have you executed, whether you are nervous or not!" "I am a poor man, Your Majesty," began the hat maker in a trembling voice, "and I had hardly started drinking tea - at most for a week or so - and the sandwich became so sparse - and the flickering of the tea - " "The flickering of what?" said the King.
"It started with the tea," replied the hat maker.
"Since when does flickering start with T?" said the King sharply.
"Are you trying to make a fool of me?"
"Go on!" "I am a poor man," the hat maker continued, "and many things flickered after all - but the March Hare said - " "Did I not say!" interrupted the March Hare hastily.
"Yes!" said the hat maker.
"I deny it!" replied the March Hare.

"He denies it," said the King, "leave that out." "Well, anyway, the dormouse said—" continued the Hatter, looking around anxiously to see if she would deny it too; but the dormouse denied nothing because it was fast asleep.
"After that," the Hatter continued, "I spread more buttered bread—" "But what did the dormouse say?" asked one of the jurors.
"I can't remember that," said the Hatter.
"You must remember," remarked the King, "otherwise I will have you executed." The unfortunate Hatter dropped the teacup and the buttered bread and knelt down.
"I am a miserable man, Your Majesty," he began.
"You are a very miserable speaker," said the King.
Here one of the guinea pigs broke into cheers and was immediately silenced by the court attendants.
(Since this is quite a harsh word, I would like to briefly explain how it was done.)
They had a large linen sack that was tied at the top with strings: they put the guinea pig in headfirst and sat on it.) "I am glad to see this," thought Alice.

"I have read so often at the end of a trial in the newspapers, 'There were attempts at applause that were immediately suppressed by the court attendants,' and until now I had never understood what that meant." "If that's all you know about it, you may sit down," continued the King.
"It can't go any deeper," said the Hatter, "I'm already on the ground." "Then you may sit down," replied the King.
Here the other guinea pig broke into cheers and was silenced.

"So, we are rid of the guinea pigs," thought Alice, "now we will make better progress." "I would rather finish my tea," said the Hatter with an anxious glance at the Queen, who was still reading from the list of singers.
"You may go," said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the hall without even taking the time to put on his shoes.
"—and behead him right outside," the Queen added to one of the court attendants, but before he reached the door, the Hatter was out of sight.
"Call the next witness!" commanded the king.
The next witness was the duchess's cook.
She held the pepper shaker in her hand, and even before she entered the hall, Alice had guessed who it was, for the people at the door all began to sneeze at once.
"Make your statement!" said the king.
"No," said the cook.

The king looked worriedly at the White Rabbit, who said in a quiet voice: "Your Majesty must cross-examine this witness." "Yes, if I must, I must," said the king in a melancholic tone, and after crossing his arms and furrowing his brow so much that his eyes were hardly visible, he said in a deep voice: "What are tarts made of?" "Of pepper, mainly," said the cook.
"Syrup," said a sleepy voice behind her.
"Grab that dormouse by the collar!" shrieked the queen.
"Behead that dormouse!"
"Throw that dormouse out of the hall!"
"Stop her!"
"Pinch her!"
"Down with her whiskers!" For a few minutes, while the dormouse was being thrown out, the whole courtroom was in chaos, and when they all sat down again, the cook had disappeared.
"It doesn't matter!" said the king in a tone of great relief.
"Call the next witness." And he spoke softly to the queen: "Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness."

"It gives me a headache." Alice watched the White Rabbit as it went through the list and was very curious about who the next witness would be, "– because not much has been said so far," she said to herself.
Imagine their surprise when the White Rabbit exclaimed with all the power of its shrill little voice: "Alice!"

translations: "Here!" shouted Alice and completely forgot in her momentary excitement how big she had become in the last few minutes, and she jumped up so hastily that she knocked over the jury box with her dress and sent the jurors tumbling onto the heads of the crowd, where they flailed around and strongly reminded Alice of the goldfish bowl she had accidentally knocked over a week ago.

"The trial cannot proceed," said the King in a very serious voice, "until all jurors are back in their proper places – all," he repeated with great emphasis, looking sternly at Alice.
Alice looked at the jury box and noticed that in her haste she had set the lizard upside down, and the poor little thing was sadly waving its tail back and forth and was completely unable to move.

She took it out again and set it right; "not that it matters much," she said to herself, "I believe it contributes to the trial in one position just as much as in the other." As soon as the jurors had recovered a little from their shock and had found and been handed their slates and pencils, they set to work very diligently writing an account of the accident, only the lizard seemed too shaken to do anything other than sit there with its mouth open and stare at the ceiling.
"What do you know about this matter?" said the King to Alice.
"Nothing," said Alice.
"Nothing at all?" insisted the King.
"Nothing at all," said Alice.
